docs.lead_paragraph: Responding to impassioned pleas from developing countries desperately seeking a vaccine to fight the AIDS epidemic, an ethics panel convened by the United Nations is recommending major changes in the way experimental vaccines are tested in people. Earlier guidelines, intended to prevent exploitation, called for testing any experimental AIDS vaccine in the country where it was made before testing it in a developing country. But today, after a two-day meeting, the panel recommended that such trials be allowed to take place in any country, including those in the third world, even if not first tested in the manufacturer's country.

headline.main: Ethics Panel Urges Easing of Curbs on AIDS Vaccine Tests

docs.abstract: Ethics panel convened by United Nations is recommending major changes in way experimental vaccines are tested in people, in response to impassioned pleas from developing countries that are desperately seeking vaccine to fights AIDS epidemic; earlier guidelines, intended to prevent exploitation, have had unintended effect of impeding possible vaccine trials in many developing countries; panel now recommends that trials of vaccines be allowed to take place in any country, including those in third world, even if not first tested in manufacturer's country (M)
docs.snippet: Responding to impassioned pleas from developing countries desperately seeking a vaccine to fight the AIDS epidemic, an ethics panel convened by the United Nations is recommending major changes in the way experimental vaccines are tested in people.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: The 221st session of the New York State Legislature ground to a close at 6:02 P.M. on June 19, not with the usual lofty declarations of achievement and unity, but with a general acknowledgment by lawmakers that, in an election year of partisan attacks and personal animus, many important issues were left unaddressed. There were, in essence, two sessions. The first began with modest agendas but fairly high hopes, and culminated in April along with the Legislature's budget negotiations, conducted in public for the first time, and the earliest passage of a budget in five years.

headline.main: Summary of Major Actions of the 221st Session of the Legislature

docs.abstract: Summary of major actions taken by New York State Legislature during its 221st session; photo (M)

byline.original: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA and RAYMOND HERNANDEZ

docs.lead_paragraph: LUIS A. PEREZ drove his 1989 Honda Accord through the high iron gate of Drumthwacket in Princeton this month and felt disbelief and exhilaration as he took in the expansive lawn with sycamore, linden and beech trees leading up to the 19th-century Greek Revival mansion that serves as the Governor's official residence. ''I'm somebody from the ghetto, and to go to a place like this was beautiful,'' said Mr. Perez, one of 35 people who graduated that night from a program that teaches leaders from urban neighborhoods how to develop their skills further to help those neighborhoods.
docs.abstract: Article on Neighborhood Leadership Initiative, program sponsored by Community Foundation of New Jersey that trains urban neighborhood leaders how to develop skills; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Six years ago, when Dr. David A. Kessler was new to the job of Commissioner of Food and Drugs, he flew to Kansas to ask a woman he had never met to become one of his chief deputies. Dr. Jane E. Henney, a cancer specialist who was an administrator at the University of Kansas School of Medicine, had a reputation, Dr. Kessler said, for being ''very smart, very talented, very independent-minded.'' For the next two years, Dr. Henney managed the daily activities of the Food and Drug Administration, a vast agency with 9,000 employees and a mandate to monitor the safety of $1 trillion worth of products each year. Before leaving in 1994 to become vice president for Health Sciences at the University of New Mexico, she hired many of the top officials who now work at the F.D.A.

headline.main: Woman in the News: Jane Ellen Henney; For F.D.A., an Old Hand

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton nominates Dr Jane E Henney to head Food and Drug Administration; her career includes stint as top aide to Dr David A Kessler, who left post 16 months ago; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ON the surface, the couple from Queens seemed like perfect candidates for Viagra. The woman, 53, has been married to her husband, 59, for 30 years. A few years ago, he started to have trouble achieving an erection. He was unhappy about it, but learned to see some good in it. ''My eye doesn't wander anymore,'' he said, ''because I can't do anything about it.'' Though the woman said she ''could not imagine staying in a relationship without sex,'' she, too, became reconciled once they learned to have other kinds of intimacy and other forms of sex.

headline.main: Viagra's Other Side Effect: Upsets in Many a Marriage

docs.abstract: Experts on sexuality and therapists are finding that Viagra and other impotence aids may actually throw into chaos relationships that have fallen into their own routine, sexual dysfunction and all; they say most common problem is that men hope to treat their impotence as simple mechanical issue, while women tend to want to address emotions related to impotence; in other cases, a man and a woman are forced to confront their divergent views about what it means to have sex and how often they want to have it--issues that impotence had rendered moot; many couples are finding that a solution to what they thought was a medical problem may uncover myriad other issues in relationship; drawings (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Four years after the North American Free Trade Agreement lowered trade barriers, the cities along Texas' long border with Mexico that had hoped to benefit are instead struggling to become more than glorified truck stops as they watch their manufacturing jobs go south by the thousands. Almost everywhere else in the United States, the economy is booming; the national unemployment rate is the lowest in nearly 30 years. In Texas university towns like Austin and College Station, employers complain of deep labor shortages.

headline.main: Free Trade's Benefits Bypass Border Towns

docs.abstract: Four years after North American Free Trade Agreement lowered trade barriers between US and Mexico, cities along Texas border that had hoped to benefit are instead struggling to become more than glorified truck stops as they watch manufacturing jobs go south by thousands; unemployment has persisted at two and three times national rate in border areas and wages remain far below state and national averages; even though NAFTA has created jobs in warehouses and truck depots that line highways, it has moved thousands more low-skill, low-wage factory jobs, mainstay of border economy, across Rio Grande; many unemployed workers are at center of problem facing border cities that once marketed themselves as sources of cheap labor; as they struggle to attract better-paying higher-skill jobs they are faced with population of swelling but poor Mexican immigrants who are ill-equipped for them; experts warn border, with three of nation's 10 fastest growing metropolitan areas, faces fuiture growth without prosperity; photo; map; chart (L)
